Award.AwardTitle: Landscapes, Barriers, and the Militarization of Everyday Life Along the U.S.-Mexican Border

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Long a space of cultural and economic convergence, the border between Mexico and the United States has increasingly become a place of division and suspicion. This transformation has resulted from the interrelated national security concerns of the Mexican and U.S. governments regarding immigration, drug trafficking, and the growth of criminal organizations. Both the Mexican and U.S. governments have chosen to address these concerns through "militarization" -- the inclusion of military ideology, tactics, technologies, and force in domestic governance and policing. This research project will investigate how militarized approaches to border governance and territorial control reconfigure everyday life for residents of the borderland. The investigators' objectives are to study how border militarization alters the form, function, and meaning of the U.S.-Mexico borderlands for resident communities and to examine how militarization is shaped by border landscapes on both sides of the divide. Special attention will be given to militarization of the borderlands as expressed and evident in the region's landscape as well as how federal militarization as a governance strategy affects the everyday experience of mobility, rights, belonging, and environment among diverse border populations. A multidisciplinary team with scholars from the U.S., Mexico, and Canada will conduct this study in two binational border metropolises of El Paso, Texas-Ciudad Juarez, Chihuahua and Nogales, Arizona-Nogales, Sonora. As strategic points in federal militarization strategies, these cities regularly experience an increased presence of law enforcement as well as intensifying surveillance, interrogation, and searches. They also share some of the longest histories of joint families, communities, and economies along the border. The investigators will engage in archival research, open-ended interviews, and focus groups, all of which will be designed to investigate the multiple intersections of militarization and landscape and to mine the complexity of these intersections within daily life.

The project will enhance basic knowledge about the processes of border militarization, its impacts on residents, and its interaction with landscape. In addition to enhancing fundamental understanding, it will provide information and insights for the architects and implementers of militarization strategies who seek to rectify problems created in earlier manifestations. It also will benefit citizens' organizations, environmental organizations, and social justice groups as they react to current policies and try to shape future ones. Results will be disseminated in both English and in Spanish in academic and policy-oriented journals and will be presented at appropriate international and regional conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is a bi-national study that investigates how, over the last two decades, changing approaches to national security within Mexico and the United States have affected everyday life for residents who live along both sides of the shared border. One important political change studied has been what is referred to as the “militarization” of civilian border and policing forces in each country. By “militarization,” the project refers to the military ideology, tactics, technologies, and approach to territorial control that have been undertaken by both the U.S. and Mexican governments since the early 1990s as the principal measures used to patrol their mutual border and to organize national security measures along it. The study has found that communities on both sides have experienced an intensification of militarization across and along the border and its adjacent borderlands. A major finding is that militarization has directly affected how people understand their citizenship rights, their access to public spaces, and their sense of security in relation to mobility across the border region. A second major finding is that militarization on both sides of the political divide has altered the experience of both the physical and social landscape for border communities. This latter finding derives from the study’s approach to the idea of landscape as both a physical and social entity and, consequently, investigates how people experience changes in infrastructure and policing as they move through and understand their border landscape.

 

The field work portion of the study was conducted in two bi-national border sites. One binational site is: El Paso, Texas and Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua. The other binational border site is: Nogales, Arizona and Nogales, Sonora. As strategic points in border governance areas for both countries, these binational sites have experienced many changes in national security policy and implementation over the last twenty years. They also share some of the longest histories of joint families, communities, economies, and environmental resources along the border. To understand the broader implications of the topics under study, the project employed three principal methods to achieve its goals: Document research, open-ended interviews, and the participatory method of focus groups. These methods are designed to investigate the multiple intersections of militarization and landscape and to mine the complexity of these intersections within daily life. These methods are designed to provide depth along with breadth to the research process. Participants included officials from both countries, educators, community groups, and residents who were active in border governance and educational matters.

 

The project’s intellectual merit is rooted in its investigation of border landscape as an entity formed both through physical as well as social processes.  While studies into border militarization represent a growth field across disciplines, few have examined the militarization of the borderlands as an issue of social and physical geography. Instead, most studies of border militarization have assumed a static definition of landscape and do not examine how the meaning and experience of places change along with the policies used to govern those places. Moreover, the vast majority of studies on border militarization do not approach the topic from a cross-border perspective, and those that do tend to focus on federal initiatives on one side of the border over the other. The border landscape in these studies rarely emerges as one that crisscrosses the international divide as people move across and along it in myriad ways. This project addresses these gaps in the literature by examining how federal militarization as a governance strategy affects the everyday experience of mobility, rights, sense of security, and environment among diverse border populations. Through numerous publications, community educational events, and academic presentations, the project has had and will continue to have broader impacts on scholarship, community understanding of geography, urban planning, and border policy as militarization has developed into a common practice of border management and control over the last twenty years across North America. As such, the study is significant not only to scholars but also to the architects and implementers of militarization strategies who seek to rectify problems created in earlier manifestations. It is also important to citizens’ organizations, environmental organizations, and community educators as they engage in planning and community interactions with government officials and policy implementation.
